list.name: United States
list.caption: United States consumed 19.1 million barrels per day in 2010. US consumption rises and falls with the economy and is down from recent highs.

list.name: China
list.caption: China consumed 9.2 million barrels per day in 2010. Consumption is rising must faster than production but is still low on a per person basis. China is the #2 oil importer.

list.name: Japan
list.caption: Japan consumed 4.4 million barrels per day in 2010. A significant portion of japanese consumption comes from the use of kerosene for home heating.

list.name: India
list.caption: India consumed 3.2 million barrels per day in 2010. Indian consumption has far outpaced production making India the #5 importer in 2010.

list.name: Russia
list.caption: Russia consumed 2.9 million barrels per day in 2010. Russian consumption, lower since the 1991 breakup of the Soviet Union is slowly rising again.

list.name: Brazil
list.caption: Brazil consumed 2.7 million barrels per day in 2010. Consumption is rising rapidly in Brasil, reducing the international impact of recent production increases.

list.name: Saudi Arabia
list.caption: Saudi Arabia consumed 2.6 million barrels per day in 2010. Consumption is rising rapidly. Saudi Arabia burns over 1 mbd/year in desalination plants.

list.name: Germany
list.caption: Germany consumed 2.5 million barrels per day in 2010. Consumption is slowly declining but Germany was still the #4 importer in 2010.

list.name: South Korea
list.caption: South Korea consumed 2.2 million barrels per day in 2010. As in Japan, kerosene for home heating accounts for a significant portion of Korean oil consumption

list.name: Canada
list.caption: Canada consumed 2.2 million barrels per day in 2010. Consumption has been stable while production increases leaving more oil for export to the US.

list.name: Mexico
list.caption: Mexico consumed 2.1 million barrels per day in 2010. Consumption is rising steadily.

list.name: Iran
list.caption: Iran consumed 1.8 million barrels per day in 2010. Consumption is rising steadily in Iran, eating into exports, despite a huge number of natural gas powered vehicles.

list.name: France
list.caption: France consumed 1.8 million barrels per day in 2010. French consumption and imports of oil have been steady for almost three decades. France is the #7 oil importer.

list.name: United Kingdom
list.caption: United Kingdom consumed 1.6 million barrels per day in 2010. The Piper Alpha disaster in 1988 reduced offshore production for several years. Since 2000, UK oil fields have been in steady decline.

list.name: Italy
list.caption: Italy consumed 1.5 million barrels per day in 2010. With little production of their own, increasing prices in Italy are driving down consumption.

list.name: Spain
list.caption: Spain consumed 1.4 million barrels per day in 2010. Spanish consumption increased during the boom of the previous decade. Spain is currently the #8 oil importer.

list.name: Indonesia
list.caption: Indonesia consumed 1.3 million barrels per day in 2010. A classic example of the 'Export Land Model', production has fallen behind consumption and this previous OPEC member now imports oil.

list.name: Singapore
list.caption: Singapore consumed 1.1 million barrels per day in 2010.

list.name: Netherlands
list.caption: Netherlands consumed 1.0 million barrels per day in 2010.

list.name: Taiwan
list.caption: Taiwan consumed 1.0 million barrels per day in 2010.

list.name: Thailand
list.caption: Thailand consumed 988 thousand barrels per day in 2010. Production and consumption are both rising in this net oil importer.

list.name: Australia
list.caption: Australia consumed 959 thousand barrels per day in 2010. Net imports are on the rise.

list.name: Venezuela
list.caption: Venezuela consumed 746 thousand barrels per day in 2010. Production is in decline largely due to a lack of investment while consumption is steadily rising.

list.name: Egypt
list.caption: Egypt consumed 740 thousand barrels per day in 2010. Egypt went from net exporter to net importer in 2009. The overthrow of the Mubarak regime occurred in 2010.

list.name: Iraq
list.caption: Iraq consumed 694 thousand barrels per day in 2010. Iraq's production history is chaotic because of sanctions, war and ongoing dislocation. But consumption is steadily rising.

list.name: Argentina
list.caption: Argentina consumed 618 thousand barrels per day in 2010. Trends of declining production and increasing consumption look set to soon convert Argentina into a net importer.

list.name: Belgium
list.caption: Belgium consumed 600 thousand barrels per day in 2010.

list.name: Turkey
list.caption: Turkey consumed 591 thousand barrels per day in 2010.

list.name: Malaysia
list.caption: Malaysia consumed 561 thousand barrels per day in 2010. Trends of declining production and increasing consumption look set to soon convert Malaysia into a net importer.

list.name: Poland
list.caption: Poland consumed 561 thousand barrels per day in 2010.

list.name: South Africa
list.caption: South Africa consumed 553 thousand barrels per day in 2010.

list.name: UAE
list.caption: UAE consumed 545 thousand barrels per day in 2010. Production is currently rising more slowly than consumption.

list.name: Pakistan
list.caption: Pakistan consumed 410 thousand barrels per day in 2010. Increasing oil imports have generated a sever balance of payments problem in Pakistan.

list.name: Greece
list.caption: Greece consumed 374 thousand barrels per day in 2010.

list.name: Sweden
list.caption: Sweden consumed 365 thousand barrels per day in 2010.

list.name: Kuwait
list.caption: Kuwait consumed 354 thousand barrels per day in 2010. Production has recently declined slightly. Oilfield damage resulting from the 1990 Iraqi invasion is obvious.

list.name: Hong Kong SAR China
list.caption: Hong Kong SAR China consumed 333 thousand barrels per day in 2010.

list.name: Vietnam
list.caption: Vietnam consumed 320 thousand barrels per day in 2010. Production has stabilized after a rapid rise but consuption is still rising. Net exports are in decline.

list.name: Algeria
list.caption: Algeria consumed 312 thousand barrels per day in 2010. Production and net exports are up over the last decade.

list.name: Philippines
list.caption: Philippines consumed 310 thousand barrels per day in 2010.

list.name: Chile
list.caption: Chile consumed 303 thousand barrels per day in 2010.

list.name: Colombia
list.caption: Colombia consumed 296 thousand barrels per day in 2010. Production has risen recently and is anticipated to increase to 1.2 mbd by 2012.

list.name: Ukraine
list.caption: Ukraine consumed 296 thousand barrels per day in 2010. Ukrainian oil consumption is down sharply since the fall of the Soviet Union.

list.name: Syria
list.caption: Syria consumed 292 thousand barrels per day in 2010. The production peak is evident but the events of 2011 will dramatically alter both production and consumption

list.name: Libya
list.caption: Libya consumed 289 thousand barrels per day in 2010. The recent revolution in Lybia means that Lybian production and net exports will look very different for 2011.

list.name: Nigeria
list.caption: Nigeria consumed 279 thousand barrels per day in 2010. Production, consumption and net exports are relatively stable.

list.name: Austria
list.caption: Austria consumed 277 thousand barrels per day in 2010.

list.name: Portugal
list.caption: Portugal consumed 272 thousand barrels per day in 2010.

list.name: Switzerland
list.caption: Switzerland consumed 254 thousand barrels per day in 2010.

list.name: Kazakhstan
list.caption: Kazakhstan consumed 249 thousand barrels per day in 2010. Production and net exports are up significantly.

list.name: Israel
list.caption: Israel consumed 238 thousand barrels per day in 2010.

list.name: Norway
list.caption: Norway consumed 213 thousand barrels per day in 2010. A perfect example of a geologically determined 'production peak'.

list.name: Finland
list.caption: Finland consumed 212 thousand barrels per day in 2010.

list.name: Morocco
list.caption: Morocco consumed 209 thousand barrels per day in 2010.

list.name: Ecuador
list.caption: Ecuador consumed 201 thousand barrels per day in 2010. Since 2004, net exports have been in steady decline. The 1987 earthquake halved exports.

list.name: Czech Republic
list.caption: Czech Republic consumed 196 thousand barrels per day in 2010.

list.name: Romania
list.caption: Romania consumed 196 thousand barrels per day in 2010. Romania was the most important source of oil for Nazi Germany but is now in long term decline.

list.name: Peru
list.caption: Peru consumed 189 thousand barrels per day in 2010.

list.name: Cuba
list.caption: Cuba consumed 176 thousand barrels per day in 2010.

list.name: Denmark
list.caption: Denmark consumed 167 thousand barrels per day in 2010. Danish production displays a well defined peak. Net exports have entered a steady decline.

list.name: Qatar
list.caption: Qatar consumed 166 thousand barrels per day in 2010. Better known for natural gas production, oil production is also up steeply in Qatar.

list.name: Ireland
list.caption: Ireland consumed 164 thousand barrels per day in 2010.

list.name: Belarus
list.caption: Belarus consumed 163 thousand barrels per day in 2010.

list.name: Yemen
list.caption: Yemen consumed 157 thousand barrels per day in 2010. Yemen is well past peak production. Current unrest will likely reduce production quantities.

list.name: New Zealand
list.caption: New Zealand consumed 155 thousand barrels per day in 2010.

list.name: Puerto Rico
list.caption: Puerto Rico consumed 150 thousand barrels per day in 2010.

list.name: Hungary
list.caption: Hungary consumed 146 thousand barrels per day in 2010.

list.name: Uzbekistan
list.caption: Uzbekistan consumed 144 thousand barrels per day in 2010.

list.name: Oman
list.caption: Oman consumed 142 thousand barrels per day in 2010.

list.name: Dominican Republic
list.caption: Dominican Republic consumed 119 thousand barrels per day in 2010.

list.name: Turkmenistan
list.caption: Turkmenistan consumed 119 thousand barrels per day in 2010.

list.name: Lebanon
list.caption: Lebanon consumed 106 thousand barrels per day in 2010.

list.name: Azerbaijan
list.caption: Azerbaijan consumed 104 thousand barrels per day in 2010. The world's first oil well was drilled in 1846 in Azerbaijan. Production and net exports are up significantly.

list.name: Bangladesh
list.caption: Bangladesh consumed 98 thousand barrels per day in 2010.

list.name: Croatia
list.caption: Croatia consumed 98 thousand barrels per day in 2010.

list.name: Jordan
list.caption: Jordan consumed 98 thousand barrels per day in 2010.

list.name: Sudan
list.caption: Sudan consumed 98 thousand barrels per day in 2010. Production and net exports are up significantly. The recent partition of North and South may impact this trend.

list.name: Panama
list.caption: Panama consumed 97 thousand barrels per day in 2010.

list.name: Sri Lanka
list.caption: Sri Lanka consumed 92 thousand barrels per day in 2010.

list.name: Bulgaria
list.caption: Bulgaria consumed 91 thousand barrels per day in 2010.

list.caption: Serbia consumed 88 thousand barrels per day in 2010.

list.name: Kenya

list.name: Angola
